label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, August 19, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, regarding a law suit they are planning to bring against the government, business affairs of Medway Plantation, and telling her of the drills they have to do on the Navy ship every morning. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss teaching their relative, Fifi, how to do the bookkeeping after her husbands death and a lunch he and Morris had with their Aunt Kate.

August 19, 1942
Dear Fat Ears,
I am telephoning you to-night and at
that time will give you my ideas on the Government
suit. However in order to confirm what we will say
I will put it in writing now.
I think it would be a gaod idea for you
to telephone Charlie Biddle at his house and tell him
the situatition, and ask whether he thinks we should
delay our suit or at least start it now. In my H
opinion George Buist will keep putting it off and off
until eventually there will not be any suit. However
there is one poiht that may prevent our suing now.
That is I am in the Navy and you are in strategic
services and no one in the employ of the Government or
in the armed forces may sue the government. This may
necessitate our waiting to sue until the war is over.
However please get in touch with Charlie and get his
opinion.
The men on theplantation can hunt with
Henry Lowndes if they want to, they do not have to.
I told them they could and asked Henry to ask them as
I thought it would give them a good time and keep them
happy. However if they are going to prexkdn pretend
that this is a chore, why then tell them they can't hunt.
I mn.so glad you are having Clippy[s ashes
buried in Grandmothers garden. He loved it so and
use to always snuffle among'st the bushes there. I
know that will be another place he will walk with us whe
I return. That week was terrible for you darling and
I am so sorry that I was not there to help you. I think
you were wonderful to have taken care of him and
continued your job and I send you my aemiration.
We leave by Navy plane tomorrow morning
for San Diego. There we are supposed to embark 
for Honlulu, but I still doubt it. Do you realize that
I was detached from duty in Washington the 25rd. of
July and this Saturday will be the twenty third again.
Just one month with nothing to do, and drawing a salary
for it. I have gotten into snch a frame of mind that
I hate the thought of working. Byt,he way, we have to
get up every morning on the boat at four oclock and stand
by the life boats. The idea is early morning is the
most dangerous from submarines, and it makes me laugh
to think of fat face getting up at that hour.
[End Page 1]
We had such a funny time last night. During the dry
we had been in town fixing up F1fi's insurance and then
we returned to the house and Morris started to show her
how to keep books. We had bought ledgers and big
thirty six column expense books. Fifi is even worse
that you about figures but Morris kept plugging ahead
and I really believe she understands it now. We finally
went to bed at twelve and this morning Fifi says she
bdreamt of numbers all night. She says if she had
a daughter she would make her learn bookkeeping
and Someth1ng;about stocks and bonds and insurance
because she knew nothing , and on Bobs death did not
even know how to start. Really if it had not been for
Morris she wouldhave been in a hell of a mess. Nobody
does anything for one except ones familly I have decided.
They all offer advice but no one gets down to the dirty
work of actually figuring things out and taking the time
to see that everything is OK. Please make ymlrself
look at figures and learn to balance your check book
Gertie, because if anything should happen to me and to
Morris there is no one who would really have your
interest at heart, and if there were two legal ways to
do a thing and one was to there advantage they would
undoubtly take it.
We lunched with Aunt Kate yesterday and
had a wonderful Italian lujhch. Spagaetti, cheese, p
and chops cooked in a wonderful sauce. Aunt Kate is
marvellous. Her eyes and mind are just as clear to
day as they ever where. She is such fun to talk to ,
but just cannot seem to take in our children. Fifi
makes it much worse by saying that I do not know where
my children are as I have not seen them for three years.
As a result Aunt Kate does not know what to believe.
Morris of course laddles out the soft soap and Aunt
Mary who is out here abso6Qtely eats 1t,and Aunt Kate
smacks her lips over dt quite a bit."Dear Morris'is
the only one that know the famllly history, who fs who
and why,etc. It is dear Moxris who keeps up with all I
the nephews and nieces etc. I am telling you that fat
face has them in the palm of his hand,
We are going down now to buy-Fifi an
adding machine so she can balance her book. She says
she may even wear an eye shrde like the real bookkeepers
do when they work.
Sweetheart you put to many stamps on you r
letters. Six cents is all you need. I asked the postman
to way your last letter and you cculdhave had it weigh
almost twice as much for six cents yet you had twelve
cents on it.
Goodbye darling, I send you all my
love.
[OVER] Sidney
[End Page 2]
after reading this letter it seems as
if I am giving a hell of a lot
of advice. I did not mean to.
The ideas just occurred to me
while I was writing. They 
sound like a sermon, when
all I meant to say "you don't
need as many stampt"
love
Sidney
[End Page 3]
